instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02098: What is 820-02098? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had liquid damage on the UG400 side of the board. Liquid damage was moderate. I cleaned the liquid damage and replaced a bunch of corroded caps and resistors. I get 20v and the board turns on and boots to the OS when using any of the ports on the left side of the mac, but the port on the right side for UG400 only gives me 5v 20ma. I checked diode mode values on all the resistors and caps around UG400 and they all seem to match with a good board. Not sure where to look next.

With charger connected to UG400:

<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC2</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC2_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> - 0.748v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_AON</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: Already replaced FG200. I have 0v on both sides of it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: Yes I have changed UG400 and there was no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: Also changed UG000, no change. Checked diode mode values on JG600 and they all match with JF600/601. It seems this <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> is not communicating with the ISL or M1 to generate PPDCIN voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Maybe not a good chip, or bad solders.

Just for test, connect a diode with A on <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC2</SIGNAL> and K on FG200.
Use 5A (or more) Schottky diode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: Does it need to be 5A? The highest I have on any of my donor boards seems to be 2A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message:
You can try, at least to see if that port switch to 20V.

I've done diode trick on few old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, where one port didn't want to work in normal mode.
The diode is needed to protect an external USB device (not charger), connected on that port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: Ok I tried that and now I get 5v 260ma for the first few seconds and then it drops to 5v 50ma.  <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC2</SIGNAL> is 5.12v but <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_AON</SIGNAL> is only 4.76v. PPBUS is now 12.01v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message:
There is something more affected by corrosion on UG400 area.
Possibly broken trace, leakage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02098</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one port stuck on 5v
threads.message: It was UF980. With the charger connected, I was getting like 2.5v on <SIGNAL>USBC2_CC1_CONN</SIGNAL> but 0v on <SIGNAL>USBC2_CC1</SIGNAL>. Replaced UF980 with a chip from a donor board and now this port gives me 20v and works correctly.
